page.title: 01General Page
page.content:
The area is predominately chalkland rising to the ridge along Inkpen Beacon.woodlands,fields of corn and fine herds of cattle are to be seen in the south of Hungerford.
Private developement side by side with local authority housing has spread southwards since 1945 over former agricultural and horticultural land. the southern extremity of the town for the foreseeable future has now been established by the planting of a tree belt of deciduous trees.
The road pattern is basically rural with the exception of the A338 which links from Oxford,through Salisbury to the South Coast. The area is honeycombed with public footpaths and bridle ways,some of which date back from medieval times.
